abstract: Recent findings suggest that beliefs about religious or spiritual importance or attending religious/spiritual services may protect high‐risk offspring against depression. This research has not extended to examining religiosity in relation to psychosocial functioning in high‐risk offspring.

title: RELIGIOSITY AND LONGITUDINAL CHANGE IN PSYCHOSOCIAL FUNCTIONING IN ADULT OFFSPRING OF DEPRESSED PARENTS AT HIGH RISK FOR MAJOR DEPRESSION
